title: If I loved Dune by Frank Herbert, what should I read next? - Quora

response.answer_text: Dune Messiah. Now, that’s obviously the next book in the series so I’m sure you’re considering it, but as I look at answers I don’t see anyone say just “Dune Messiah”, they’re all talking about committing to at least 2 more novels in the story, so I think it’s appropriate to understand why Dune Messiah is a book I consider essential and nothing after is: Dune Messiah completely the original trilogy of Paul Atreides life. What’s that you say? Isn’t Messiah the 2nd book in the series? Yes but: “Dune” was not written as a novel. It’s a series of stories bound together.“Dune” can in fact be seen as a story of 2 “novels” which in total encompass 400+ pages. “Dune Messiah” is a 200+ page story that fits in as the “3rd novel” of the series.“Dune” doesn’t really have an ending. I mean, it’s ended with a nice touch, but it’s an ending that says “Okay, what’s Paul do next”. I’ll refrain from going into details here but the ending to “Dune Messiah” is far more definite, far more dramatic, and far more cathartic.When I think of Paul’s prescience, the scene that I think really demonstrates it best, and gives chills like no other, happens in “Dune Messiah”.The upcoming adapatation by Villeneuve appears to be following what I consider this natural organizational structure covering only about half of “Dune”. This undoubtedly seems crazy who consider “Dune” to be THE masterpiece, but once you realize that the best way to make a “Lord of the Rings” style trilogy is to end with “Dune Messiah” this becomes the clear way to do it. I’m impressed that Villeneuve thought this way, though I was already impressed with him after “The Arrival” and “Blade Runner” so his exquisite taste is no longer a surprise.If you’re looking for another immersive book series, here’s a recent one: The Broken Earth Trilogy in Order by N. K. Jemisin

Well there are the sequels and you could try the Dune books written by his son Brian Herbert & Kevin A Anderson but they are not anywhere as good, well there is a sizable amount of people who think they are the equivilent of digging up Frank Herbetrs corpse and riding the burning cadaver down a street. Lets just say I found them disappointing particularly the Legends of Dune stuff. For a good read I recommend the Hyperion Cantos by Dan Simmons : curiously I found this due to a fluke mention in a Japanese Anime and it was good though it was supposed to be 2 books there was the sequels set nearly 300 years later which are not so good but still worth a read. The Shrike in the first two books is a particularly striking character. For a series of books The Culture series by Iain M Banks, I used to see a rather pretty girtl who recommended books by Iain Banks such as the Crow Road which I did read, well it is the same guy. Although it does have rather ridiculous Alien sort of names it works so much better than the rather casual sci-fi naming conventions and although I am in the middle of the 3rd book they have been great.  I enjoyed the Player of Games and the particular Scottish humour which works for me one book although not not in the culture series with a particularly vile character who is invading this planetary system attacks an gas Giant inhabited by a very ancient race only to find they can defend themselves very effectively has his second in command tell him subsinctly before he is destroyed that “you are a C**t” had me laugh out loud on the bus even though I was holding on to the seat by only one buttock cheek at the time whilst going home from work.
